Bella Akhmadulina (Izabella Akhatovna Akhmadulina, born April 10, 1937 – November 29, 2010) was a celebrated Soviet and Russian poet, short story writer, and translator, known for her apolitical writing stance. Despite her avoidance of overtly political themes, Akhmadulina was often critical of authorities in the Soviet Union and spoke out in favor of others, including Nobel laureates Boris Pasternak, Andrei Sakharov, and her close friend, Bulat Okudzhava.

Akhmadulina was a prominent figure in the Russian New Wave literary movement and was cited by Joseph Brodsky as the best living poet in the Russian language. Her poetry is characterized by its use of imagery, humor, and rhymed quatrains, which she used to explore everyday, yet imaginative occurrences.

Akhmadulina's main themes included friendship, love, and relations between people. She wrote numerous essays about Russian poets and translators, some devoted to her close friend, Bulat Okudzhava. In addition to her work in Russian literature, Akhmadulina translated poetry from France, Italy, Chechnya, Poland, Yugoslavia, Hungary, Bulgaria, Georgia, Armenia, and many others.

Akhmadulina died at her home in Peredelkino near Moscow on November 29, 2010, at the age of 73, due to a heart condition. Her death was mourned by many, including Dmitry Medvedev and Vladimir Putin, who both paid tribute to her legacy. Medvedev wrote on his blog that Akhmadulina's poetry was a "classic of Russian literature," and that her death was an "irreparable loss."

Throughout her career, Akhmadulina received numerous awards and honors, including an Honorary Membership in the American Academy of Arts and Letters in 1977. Her contributions to Russian literature and culture are still widely recognized and celebrated today, cementing her place as one of the most important and influential poets of the 20th century.

IU (Lee Ji-eun), born on May 16, 1993, is a South Korean singer-songwriter and actress. She began her music career at the age of 15 with her debut album "Lost and Found" under Kakao M (formerly LOEN Entertainment) in 2007. IU quickly gained popularity with her follow-up albums "Growing Up" and "IU...IM," but it was her 2010 album "Real" that brought her mainstream success with the lead single "Good Day." This song made her a spokesmodel and in-game model for NCsoft's "Lineage II" video game, as well as part of Nexon's promotions for "Dungeon Fighter Online."

In 2011, IU became the face of Samsung Anycall and Samsung Galaxy S II for Samsung Electronics, as well as the endorsement model for clothing brands Unionbay Sportswear and Le Coq Sportif. She also appeared in commercials for South Korea's largest wireless carrier SK Telecom, Namyang Diary's Yogurt Bulgaris brand, petroleum and refinery company S-Oil, and retail chain Homeplus. IU has been the face of fast-food restaurant chain Mexicana Chicken since 2011.

In addition to her music career, IU has also pursued an acting career. She made her acting debut in 2013 with a supporting role in the television series "The Producers," which was sponsored by her endorsement brands Unionbay Sportswear and ISOI. IU continued to act in various television series and films, including "The Merciless" (2017), "Hotel Del Luna" (2019), and "Hwayugi" (2017-2018).

Throughout her career, IU has received numerous awards and accolades for her music and acting, including Best New Female Artist at the 2010 Melon Music Awards and Best Digital Song at the 2017 Mnet Asian Music Awards. She has also been named as one of the most influential people in South Korea by Forbes Korea.

IU's music style is characterized by her soulful voice and emotional lyrics, which often focus on themes of love and self-empowerment. Her songs have been praised for their relatability and catchiness, and she has been credited with helping to popularize the K-pop genre worldwide. With her versatile talent and dedication to her craft, IU continues to be a beloved figure in the Korean entertainment industry and beyond.

     Nisar Ahmad Kakru was born on October 26, 1949, in Baramulla, Kashmir, India. He served as the Chief Justice of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh from February 19, 2010, to October 26, 2011. Kakru was enrolled as a pleader in August 1975, as a vakil in February 1979, and as an advocate in April 1982. Initially, he practiced at Baramulla district and sessions courts and other courts. He was appointed as public prosecutor in the district and sessions court of Baramulla in 1978 and resigned in 1981 due to an order issued by the Government of Jammu and Kashmir. During his tenure as a judge of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court, he delivered several landmark judgments, including one holding that migrants from Doda and Poonch districts must be treated on par with migrants from Kashmir province.

After his tenure as Chief Justice of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, Kakru continued his private practice at Jammu and Kashmir High Court in civil, criminal, constitutional, service, labor, revenue, and company matters. In February 1988, he was appointed as Chief Government Advocate and Additional Advocate General at Jammu and Kashmir High Court by the Government of Jammu and Kashmir, and he resigned in 1990 due to the cease of the state government's power due to the imposition of Governor's rule in the state.

Throughout his legal career, Kakru has been dedicated to upholding justice and fairness in the legal system. His contributions to the legal field have been significant, and he is widely respected for his expertise and integrity.

After his tenure as Chief Justice of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, Kakru continued his private practice at Jammu and Kashmir High Court in civil, criminal, constitutional, service, labor, revenue, and company matters. He was only 14 years old at the time of his death and was dubbed "Joselito." His martyrdom was seen as a political venture by government officials who were attempting to stamp out dissent and crush religious freedom in the area. Despite the persecution, José refused to renounce his faith, shouting "Viva Cristo Rey!" instead of the government's demand that he declare "Death to Christ the King."

The sainthood proceedings for José began in 1996 in the diocese of Zamora and continued until 1997, when the Congregation for the Causes of Saints declared "nihil obstat" (nothing against) to the cause. This granted him the next step in the sainthood process.

Through the film "For Greater Glory," José's story is portrayed, along with the story of the Cristero War, which was a conflict between the Mexican government and Catholic rebels in the 1920s and 1930s. The film highlights the political and religious tensions that led to José's martyrdom and the persecution of other Catholics in Mexico during this time.

     Paul Kruger, also known as "Oom Paul," was a prominent political and military figure in 19th-century South Africa. He served as President of the South African Republic (or Transvaal) from 1883 to 1900 and became a symbol of Afrikanerdom. Kruger was a controversial figure, with some viewing him as a tragic folk hero and others criticizing his role in the Second Boer War against Britain.

Kruger was born on October 10, 1825, in the Transvaal region of South Africa. He came from a family of modest means and was largely self-educated. Kruger's political career began in the 1850s, when he became involved in the resistance movement against British rule in the Transvaal. He was elected as a member of the Volksraad, the Transvaal's parliament, in 1864 and served as president of the republic from 1883 until 1900.

During his presidency, Kruger faced increasing tensions with Britain over the Transvaal's independence. In 1899, these tensions erupted into the Second Boer War, which lasted until 1902. Kruger was the face of the Boer cause, and his leadership during the war earned him both admiration and criticism. Some saw him as a courageous and determined leader, while others criticized his tactics and the suffering he caused among civilians.

Kruger's legacy is complex and controversial. He is often portrayed as a tragic folk hero, a symbol of Afrikanerdom and resistance against British rule. However, his role in the Second Boer War and his support for apartheid have also been criticized. Despite these criticisms, Kruger remains a significant figure in South African history and continues to be studied and debated by historians and political analysts.

In addition to his political career, Kruger was also known for his personal qualities. He was described as a charismatic leader with a strong sense of humor and a talent for oratory. He was also known for his love of music and his ability to play several instruments.

Kruger's legacy has been the subject of much debate and controversy over the years. Some have praised him as a hero and a symbol of Afrikaner identity, while others have criticized him for his role in the Second Boer War and his support for apartheid. Despite these criticisms, Kruger remains an important figure in South African history and continues to be studied and debated by historians and political analysts.
